author: Paul Gilder
title: Gordon turns to Nine Entertainment | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The
text:
TELEVISION magnate Bruce Gordon has set tongues wagging after his regional broadcaster, Win Corporation, snapped up a 13 per cent stake in Nine Entertainment.
A private investment company owned by Mr Gordon is buying the stake from US hedge fund Apollo Global Management, which will be left with a 9 per cent holding.
Mr Gordon already has strong ties with Nine, which owns the Nine Network and supplies content to Win, and the parties are in negotiations over the pricing of their next content deal.
The move by the billionaire comes as the industry lobbies the new Federal Cabinet for ­reforms, including scrapping the so-called “reach rule”.
Under the rule, which is widely considered outdated in the digital age, no single TV operator can broadcast to more than 75 per cent of the population, creating a major barrier to potential mergers.
Yesterday’s announcement means Mr Gordon now boasts sizeable stakes in two of the country’s three major free-to-air networks.
He has a 14.95 per cent stake in Nine and a 15 per cent holding in Ten Network.
Mr Gordon has been anything but a passive investor in Ten. He used his stake to oppose a $590 million takeover offer from Foxtel — which is half owned by Herald Sun publisher News Corp — and US cable heavyweight Discovery Communications.
Analysts said his latest move gave him plenty of bargaining power in a rapidly changing media landscape.
“The question is, what’s the end game? Is he trying to block anything that could work against him?” IG market analyst Evan Lucas said.
“He’s clearly ahead of the curve and knows a lot more about the media game in this country than I do.”
Morningstar analyst Brian Han said yesterday Mr Gordon could be agitating for a board seat at Nine to play a role in anointing a successor to its chief executive, David ­Gyngell.
The network has begun a search for someone to replace Mr Gyngell.
The Nine transaction is due to be completed on November 9.
Shares in Nine closed down 3c at $1.585 yesterday.
